text: Now therefore swear unto me here by God that thou wilt not deal falsely with me, nor with my son, nor with my son's son: but according to the kindness that I have done unto thee, thou shalt do unto me, and to the land wherein thou hast sojourned.
text_kjv: Now therefore swear unto me here by God that thou wilt not deal falsely with me, nor with my son, nor with my son's son: but according to the kindness that I have done unto thee, thou shalt do unto me, and to the land wherein thou hast sojourned.
text_niv: Now swear to me here before God that you will not deal falsely with me or my children or my descendants. Show to me and the country where you are living as an alien the same kindness I have shown to you.”
text_esv: Now therefore swear to me here by God that you will not deal falsely with me or with my descendants or with my posterity, but as I have dealt kindly with you, so you will deal with me and with the land where you have sojourned.”
text_nlt: “Swear to me in God’s name that you will never deceive me, my children, or any of my descendants. I have been loyal to you, so now swear that you will be loyal to me and to this country where you are living as a foreigner.”
text_msg: So swear to me that you won't do anything underhanded to me or any of my family. For as long as you live here, swear that you'll treat me and my land as well as I've treated you."
text_nasb: now therefore, swear to me here by God that you will not deal falsely with me or with my offspring or with my posterity, but according to the kindness that I have shown to you, you shall show to me and to the land in which you have sojourned.'
context: Genesis 21 narrates the birth of Isaac and the establishment of a covenant between Abraham and Abimelech, king of Gerar. The chapter highlights God's faithfulness in fulfilling his promise to Abraham and Sarah, who were now very old. Verse 23 occurs after a dispute over a well which Abraham digs and Abimelech's men seize. Abimelech, accompanied by Phicol, the commander of his army, approaches Abraham because he recognizes God's favor upon him. The request for an oath arises not out of genuine friendship, but strategic self-interest and a perceived threat from Abraham's increasing power and divine blessing. In the ancient Near East, wells were vital resources, often points of conflict. Agreements surrounding water rights were critical for peaceful coexistence. Kings would often make treaties guaranteeing protection and mutual benefit. Swearing an oath 'by God' was a solemn undertaking, invoking divine judgment if the terms were violated. Such oaths were serious legal and social contracts, more binding than modern agreements. The mention of 'son' and 'son's son' emphasizes the long-term nature of the agreement, ensuring its validity across generations. Abimelech seeks reassurance that Abraham’s growing power will not be used to harm him or his kingdom and to acknowledge the good treatment he had previously afforded Abraham. Abraham, a sojourner and thus dependent, was now in a position of strength, making Abimelech uneasy. The land where Abraham 'sojourned' lacked defined national boundaries in the modern sense; power dynamics shifted based on tribal strength and alliances.
meaning: Theologically, Genesis 21:23 reveals several important aspects of God's character and his relationship with humanity. Firstly, Abimelech's recognition of God's presence with Abraham underscores the impact of a godly life. Even those outside the covenant community could see evidence of God's favor. Secondly, the request for an oath highlights the importance of integrity and faithfulness, key values within the Abrahamic covenant. Abraham is asked to swear to treat Abimelech and his descendants with the same kindness he received, demonstrating the reciprocal nature of covenantal relationships. God's blessing is not meant to be hoarded but shared and reflected in interactions with others, even those who are not part of God's chosen people. The emphasis on 'kindness' connects to the broader theme of God's hesed (steadfast love and mercy). Abimelech acknowledges that Abraham has been treated well, implying a moral obligation for Abraham to reciprocate. This verse foreshadows the ethical requirements of the Mosaic Law, where justice and compassion are intertwined. The oath itself underscores the seriousness of covenantal agreements and their binding nature. By swearing 'by God,' both parties acknowledge a higher authority who will hold them accountable. The request for a multi-generational commitment points towards God's enduring plan of salvation, which extends through generations of faithful believers. It also implicitly recognizes the impact of one generation's faithfulness on future generations.
application: In a modern context, Genesis 21:23 calls us to examine our own relationships and how we treat those around us, especially those who have shown us kindness. Do we reciprocate kindness, or do we take advantage of others? This passage challenges us to move beyond self-interest and consider the well-being of others, even those who may not be part of our immediate circle. It speaks to the importance of honoring our commitments and agreements, both personal and professional. In a world often characterized by broken promises and fleeting relationships, Genesis 21:23 reminds us of the value of integrity and faithfulness. It encourages us to be people of our word, whose actions align with our values. The principle of treating others with the same kindness we have received applies to various aspects of life, including work, family, community, and even our interactions with strangers. Consider how you treat your neighbors, colleagues, and family members. Are you extending kindness and compassion, or are you focusing solely on your own needs? Furthermore, this verse highlights the importance of building bridges and fostering positive relationships with those who may hold different beliefs or come from different backgrounds. Just as Abraham made a covenant with Abimelech, we can seek to establish common ground and build trust with people who may not share our worldview. In a globalized world, this principle is particularly relevant as we navigate cultural differences and strive for peaceful coexistence. Finally, Genesis 21:23 reminds us that our actions have long-term consequences. The oath was meant to extend to future generations. Similarly, our choices today will impact the lives of those who come after us. We should strive to create a legacy of kindness, faithfulness, and integrity that will positively influence future generations.
prayer: Heavenly Father, thank you for your steadfast love and kindness towards us. Forgive us for the times we have failed to reciprocate the kindness shown to us. Help us to be people of integrity, who honor our commitments and treat others with compassion. Grant us wisdom to build bridges and foster positive relationships with those around us, even those who are different from us. May our actions reflect your love and grace, and may we leave a legacy of kindness for future generations. Help us to remember that our relationships are a reflection of our relationship with you. Teach us to act justly, love mercy, and walk humbly with you. In Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: Abimelech likely recognized God's blessing on Abraham, leading to increasing prosperity and power. Fearful of Abraham's growing influence, Abimelech sought a treaty to ensure peaceful coexistence and protect his own kingdom from potential harm. He also acknowledged Abraham's upright character.
